Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating the Relationship between Suction and Pressure as Applied by an Infant during Breastfeeding
Award.AbstractNarration:
Successful breastfeeding requires frequent removal of milk from the breasts. Infants use both pressure and suction to remove milk from the breast. Infants are more efficient than hand expression, which utilizes only pressure, or mechanical pumps, which utilize only vacuum. The PI, in collaboration with Dr. Donna Geddes, will utilize the equipment and techniques developed by the Hartmann Human Lactation Research Group in Perth, Australia, to collect clinical data from mother-infant nursing pairs to establish a range of normal values for both pressure and suction in relationship to milk flow as seen in healthy infants nursing at the breast.

The importance of breastfeeding is widely acknowledged but difficulty with milk removal is a leading cause for women to stop breastfeeding. While artificial means to express milk exist, women are more likely to experience problems with milk stasis with these methods when compared to infant milk removal at the breast. Artificial milk removal techniques currently utilize only one form of pressure ? vacuum or compression. Extensive research has examined the intra-oral vacuum created by infant suckling, but none has ever explored the oral peripheral pressure applied by the infant. This research will utilize specialized pressure sensors to measure the oral peripheral pressure while measuring all other forces and movements with the specialized equipment available at the Hartmann Human Lactation Research Group in Perth, Australia, led by Dr. Donna Geddes. The results of this study will define the relative importance of each form of pressure in breastfeeding and advance the understanding of milk removal for both the scientific and medical community.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The importance of breastfeeding is widely acknowledged but current breastfeeding rates in both the U.S. and worldwide are far below the recommended standards set by the World Health Organization. To sustain lactation requires frequent removal of milk from the breast. Difficulty with milk removal is a leading cause for early cessation of breastfeeding among women. The challenges surrounding frequent milk removal are compounded by the increasing number of mothers working outside the home that need to express milk when separated from their infants.

Infant led milk removal remains the most efficient means to maintain lactation long term. Infants utilize both positive and negative pressures on the breast during suckling. The relationship between positive and negative pressures as exerted by infants on the breast is complex and not well understood. The purpose of this award was to gain a better understanding of the pressures applied by infants during breastfeeding by utilizing the equipment and techniques developed at the Hartmann Human Lactation Research Group in Perth, Australia in collaboration with Dr. Donna Geddes.

Data was collected from 8 mother-infant pairs. The peripheral oral pressures applied to the areola and the intra-oral vacuum pressures were measured. The interaction between the nipple and the infants’ oral cavity, along with milk flow, was captured via ultrasound. This data will be used in computer simulations and experimental work that is part of a larger 5-year research project.

 Although much work has been done with regards to the relationship between the intra-oral vacuum pressure and milk flow, little is known about the positive oral pressure. This experimental work, as part of a larger research project, actually captured the pressure applied to the areola by infants. The preliminary findings were reported at the 2017 Summer Biomechanics, Bioengineering, and Biotransport Conference (SB3C). A more thorough paper is under development and will contribute to the broader literature on breastfeeding biomechanics and lactation biotransport phenomena.

 In addition to expanding the scientific understanding of lactation and breastfeeding, the findings of this project will have broader impacts by contributing to our understanding of milk flow within the human breast that will positively impact breastfeeding women worldwide. The data obtained can be used to design more efficient breast pumps for working women and develop better techniques for dealing with milk stasis within the breast. The grant has enabled the PI to form relationships that will likely develop into future international collaborations, as well as, mentor undergraduate female engineering students both in and out of the lab. The PI was awarded a travel grant to present these findings at SB3C which provided her the opportunity to serve in a leadership role as co-chair of the Student Leadership Committee of ASME Bioengineering Division.

 


Last Modified: 08/02/2017
Modified by: Diana L Alatalo
